comments.content: If action is going to configure in business process flow, the input parameter cannot be an option set type in action step.

discussion.content:
There is six types of user inputs:Text, Yes/No, File, Email, Number, Date.
So, answer is No.
Action with Input parameter as Entity, Entity Reference or Option sets are not allowed for BPF action steps.

Selected Answer: B
There is six types of user inputs:Text, Yes/No, File, Email, Number, Date.
So, answer is No.
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1oNH9i2ssNi9gISG3JGuxUoUhmAA4xCaGahEKv2dRN6Y/edit?usp=sharing

Selected Answer: B
B, No doubt.
It should be a Two Options field. Basically a checkbox Yes/No
seems correct "You need to complete configuration of the business process flow." configuring an option set has no impact on a BPF

questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You are configuring a business process flow for a case entity.
All cases must be flagged for review.
You need to complete configuration of the business process flow.
Solution: Set the input parameter type as Option set for the action.
Does the solution meet the goal?

HOTSPOT -
You are a Dynamics 365 for Customer Service administrator.
You need to manage business process flows.
What should you configure? To answer, select the appropriate configuration in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Answer 1: Order
You can also set the order of the business process flows so that you can control which business process flow will be set by default.

Answer 2: Stage
Each stage contains a group of steps. Each step represents a field where data can be entered. People advance to the next stage by using the Next Stage button.

1. Process Flow Order, definitely > To arrange which BPFs will be shown first. 
2. Stage > It is about wording. Show ACTIONS not ACTION. A stage contains several data steps (actions) while a step is an action.
I think it is talking about the default order of the flows, so it is Order & Stage for the answers

I'd go with Order and Stage. 
For the 2nd one, it was stated in the details that this is about managing the business process flow, thus the action that CSR needs to complete are the STAGES.

The question is: What should you configure to show actions that must be completed by the user.
1. If you configure Step - you can show 1 action only
2. if you configure Stage which contains several steps you can show multiple actions that need to be completed.
I would suggest: Stage
And what do you think?

comments.content: I think it should be steps

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You are implementing Dynamics 365 for Customer Service.
You need to set up available working hours to help desk representatives who have varying schedules.
What should you do? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//

discussion.content: I think it should be A because in order to configure a different schedule per user, you have to go to Settings-->Security-->Users-->Work Hours. Thoughts?

comments.content:
I agree.
when you want to setup indivual working hours for your csr you have to do that for each csr as described above.
In the Customer Server Calendar you can setup the Support Schedules in genaral but not for each csr.

you say "I think it should be A", but in your comment you call it it can not be A since you have to go to Settings to define hours for each user account. 

so the given answers are correct?

discussion.content: Guys guys!!! it is "Individual Working Hours" or "Working Hours for each individual". THe answer is correct.

I think A is correct. Question is referring to reps who have varying schedule. On the other hand, Customer Service Calendars apply as a whole over an SLA. I am not sure if they work for reps on individual level. Do they?

The questions says "working hours to help desk representatives who have varying schedules"...Schedules, not hours. You are therefore wanting to set varying schedules, not individual user hours. So IMO the answer is correct.
So, it the solution they provided the correct answer? Thank you

Vary by day (also this term is exactly same term on the Web Refresh interface)
